A '''security switch''' is hardware protection device for [[computer]],[[laptop]], [[smartphone]] and similar devices from unauthorized access or operation , different from [[virtual security switch]] which is [[software]] protection. Security switch should be operated by an authorized user only, for that it should be isolated from other devices in order to prevent unauthorized access and it should not have bypass in order to prevent manipulations.
The primary purpose of a security switch is to provide protection against '''[[Cellphone surveillance]]''', '''[[Eavesdropping]]''', '''[[Malware]]''', '''[[Spyware]]''', '''[[Cyberwarfare]]''' , '''[[Laptop theft]]''' and '''Theft''' of smartphones and similar devices. Unlike other protections or techniques, security switch can provide protection even if computer / phone security is already broken, since it does not have any access from other components and not accessible for device software. It can disconnect or block any peripheral device, perform "man in the middle" operations like isolated encryption and similar operations. Security switch (S.S.) can be used for [[human presence detection]] since signals , sent by it can be initiated by human operator only, cannot be manipulated or bypassed. S.S. also can be used as internet security hardware firewall<ref> [https://www.pandasecurity.com/usa/support/card?Id=31435] panda security </ref>.
== Problem example == Cellphone software is broken by Trojan, device start constant recording. When user activated “preventing capture of audio/video information” mode of operation on security switch, it disconnects microphone and camera and stop recording. Instead of removing microphone from device <ref> https://www.wired.com/2016/05/snowden-vice-cell-phone-hack/ </ref>
[[File:Security Switch example for smartphone.gif|Security Switch example for smartphone]]
[[File:Security switch for theft protection example.jpg|thumb]] Laptop that have embedded security switch is stolen. Internal part of security switch does not had communication from external part for 12 hours, then it disconnects screen, keyboard and other key components making laptop useless, with no possibility of recover even by replacing all software.
User does not want that someone can tack his location , he/she activated geo-location protection , security switch disconnecting RF , GRRS communication eliminating possibility of tracking device location.
User want to prevent possibility of PIN coping using smartphone , he/she activated secure input , in response security switch disconnects touch screen from main processor , so input signals are not available to other devices except security switch itself.
Security switch during scheduled monitoring found that virus program is trying to download malicious content from internet , it activates internet security shield function and disconnect computer communication , preventing download.
== History == Security switch was invented in 2007 <ref> http://www.freepatentsonline.com/8090961.html Security switch US Patent 8090961 </ref>; NIST Guidelines Cell Phone and PDA Security 2008 <ref> NIST SP 800-124 https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2206208 </ref> included "4.1.7 Deactivate compromised devices" , then Guidelines for Managing the Security of Mobile Devices in 2013 included <ref> https://www.nist.gov/publications/guidelines-managing-security-mobile-devices-enterprise </ref> : "Lack of physical security controls as threat and restrict user and application access to hardware, such as the digital camera, GPS, Bluetooth interface, USB interface, and removable storage" as General policy. At 2014 concept presented at 35th IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy.<ref> https://www.ieee-security.org/TC/SP2014/program-short_talks.html 35th IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy</ref>

1. 35th IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy https://www.ieee-security.org/TC/SP2014/program-short_talks.html. 2. Security Switch , Yoffe S,Yoffe D, http://www.freepatentsonline.com/8090961.html. 3. Secure PIN management of a user trusted device , Buhler,Peter et.al. IBM http://www.freepatentsonline.com/8423783.html. 4. DISCONNECTING A BATTERY FROM A SYSTEM , Chen,Qijun et.al. HEWLETT-PACKARD http://www.freepatentsonline.com/y2017/0269659.html .

Сергій Єфремов | caption = Serhiy Oleksandrovych Okhrimenko
at a young age | image = Yefremov.jpg | office = [[General Secretariat of Ukraine|Secretary of Nationalities]][http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?AddButton=pages\G\E\GeneralSecretariatoftheCentralRada.htm encyclopediaofukraine.com] | primeminister = [[Volodymyr Vynnychenko]] | term_start = June 28, 1917 | term_end = July 17, 1917 | predecessor = position created | successor = [[Oleksandr Shulhyn]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1876|10|18}} | birth_place = [[Kiev Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1939|03|31|1876|10|18}} (speculative) | death_place = [[Vladimir Central Prison|Vladimir]], [[Soviet Union]] | relations = | party = [[Ukrainian Democratic Party (1904)|Ukrainian Party of Socialists-Federalists]] | occupation = public and political activist, statesman, literal critic, historian of literature, academician | spouse = Halyna Yefremova | children = | signature = | magnum opus = History of the Ukrainian literature }} '''Serhiy Yefremov''' ({{lang-uk|Сергій Єфремов}}; October 18, 1876 – March 31, 1939) was a [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] literary journalist, historian, critic, political activist, statesman, and academician. He was a member of the [[Ukrainian Academy of Science]] (1919) and [[Shevchenko Scientific Society]] in [[Lviv]]. Yefremov is his literary [[Pseudonym#Concealment of identity|pseudonym]], his real name is Okhrimenko. ==Early years== Serhiy Okhrimenko was born in the village of [[Palchik]], [[Zvenigorodka uyezd]] of the [[Kiev Governorate]]. Today the village still stands, but in [[Katerynopil Raion]] of the [[Cherkasy Oblast]], the central [[Ukraine]]. He was born in a family of the [[Eastern Orthodox]] [[priest]]. In 1891-96 studied at [[National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy#History|Kievan Theological Seminary]], later graduated from the Faculty of Law of [[Kiev University]]. ==Political start== Political activity started during student years becoming the member of the Ukrainian Universal non-Party Democratic Organization. In 1904 became co-founder of the [[Ukrainian Democratic Party (1904)|Ukrainian Radical Party]], which in 1905 out of his initiative united together with the [[Ukrainian Democratic Party (1904)|Ukrainian Democratic Party]] and establishing the [[Ukrainian Democratic Radical Party]]. In 1905 became the leader of the Ukrainian Social Union (USU) ''Peasant Union''. In 1908 became the co-founder of the [[Society of Ukrainian Progressionists]]. He worked in the variety of Ukrainian periodicals such as ''Zoria'', ''Pravda'', ''[[Kievan Past]]'', ''Ukraina'' etc. In 1885-1918 he was the head of publishing ''Vik''. ==Secretariat== He was arrested numerous times by the [[Russia]]n authorities for pressing public speeches in defense of national culture and political freedoms in pre-revolutionary period. In March 1917 Okhrimenko entered the staff of the [[Central Rada]]. In April 1917, at the [[Ukrainian National Congress]] was elected as the deputy of the Head of the [[Central Rada|Rada]] and the member of the [[Mala Rada]]. On June 15, 1917 became the general secretary of the International Affairs in the newly formed Ukrainian government, [[General Secretariat of Ukraine|General Secretary]] of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].M. Mintz, "The Secretariat of Internationality Affairs (Sekretariiat mizhnatsional’nykh spray) of the Ukrainian General Secretariat 1917-1918", ''[[Harvard Ukrainian Studies]]'', Volume VI Number 1 March 1982, pp.25-42 On July 17, 1917 he was replaced by Oleksandr Shulhyn from the same political party. From September 1917 heads the [[Ukrainian Democratic Party (1904)|Ukrainian Party of Socialists-Federalists]]. From April 1918 and until 1920 he did not hold any official positions. ==Soviet Ukraine== {{See also|Union for the Freedom of Ukraine process}} With the installation of Soviet power in Ukraine was forced to go into the illegal situation and hiding. In spring 1919, at the request of the [[Ukrainian Academy of Science]], he was amnestied. From 1922 until 1928, he was one of the leaders of the Ukrainian Academy of Science. He was the chief defendant in the 1929 public [[show trial]] of the leaders of the supposed [[Union for the Liberation of Ukraine process|Union for the Liberation of Ukraine]]. In 1930, he was sentenced to death, but the sentence was later commuted to ten years in prison. He died in 1939 while in [[Vladimir Central Prison]].http://ukrainianweek.com/History/33904 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *[[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]], edited by O. J. Frederiksen. ''A History of Ukraine''. New Haven: [[Yale University Press]]: 1941. *Ihor Pidkova (editor), Roman Shust (editor), "[http://history.franko.lviv.ua/dovidnyk.htm Dovidnyk z istorii Ukrainy]", 3 Volumes, Kiev, 1993–1999, {{ISBN|5-7707-5190-8}} (t. 1), {{ISBN|5-7707-8552-7}} (t. 2), {{ISBN|966-504-237-8}} (t. 3). Article: [http://history.franko.lviv.ua/Ije.htm Єфремов Сергій Олександрович] {{uk icon}} ==External links== *[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkPath=pages\Y\E\YefremovSerhii.htm Serhii Yefremov] at the [[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]] x {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yefremov, Serhiy}} [[Category:1876 births]] [[Category:1939 deaths]] [[Category:People from Katerynopil Raion]] [[Category:People from Kiev Governorate]] [[Category:Ukrainian Democratic Party (1904) politicians]] [[Category:20th-century Ukrainian politicians]] [[Category:Foreign ministers of Ukraine]] [[Category:Members of the Central Council of Ukraine]] [[Category:Ukrainian diplomats]] [[Category:Society of Ukrainian Progressors members]] [[Category:Ukrainian historians]] [[Category:Ukrainian writers]] [[Category:Ukrainian literary critics]] [[Category:Ukrainian activists]] [[Category:Members of the Shevchenko Scientific Society]] [[Category:Union for the Freedom of Ukraine trial]] [[Category:Inmates of Vladimir Central Prison]] [[Category:Ukrainian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Ukrainian prisoners sentenced to death]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to death by the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Ukrainian people who died in Soviet detention]] [[Category:Forced disappearances in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Unpersons in the Eastern Bloc]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = Professor Emerita | name = Susan Treggiari | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | discipline = [[Classics]] | sub_discipline = [[Marriage in ancient Rome]] | movement = | religion = | denomination = | education = [[The Cheltenham Ladies' College|Cheltenham Ladies' College]]
[[Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford|Lady Margaret Hall]] | alma_mater = | thesis_title = | workplaces = [[Stanford University]] | notable_works = | awards = [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim Fellow]] (1995-96) }} '''Professor Susan Treggiari''' BA MA BLitt DLitt is an English scholar of Ancient Rome,[http://www.gf.org/fellows/14817-susan-treggiari John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130104235604/http://www.gf.org/fellows/14817-susan-treggiari |date=4 January 2013 }} emeritus professor of [[Stanford University]] and retired member of the [[Faculty of Classics, University of Oxford|Faculty of Classics]] at the [[University of Oxford]]. Her specialist areas of study are the family and marriage in ancient Rome, [[Cicero]] and the late Roman Republic. == Education == Professor Treggiari was educated at [[The Cheltenham Ladies' College|Cheltenham Ladies' College]], where she studied Latin from eleven and Greek from twelve.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/susan-m-treggiari/|title=John Simon Guggenheim Foundation - Susan M. Treggiari|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=17 March 2017}} She studied Literae Humaniores at [[Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford]] from 1958–62, for which she was awarded a first, remaining for a further two years and writing a thesis supervised by [[Peter Brunt|P.A. Brunt]], on ''Roman freedmen during the late Republic'' (published by the Clarendon Press, 1969). She held a Derby Scholarship for travel in Italy 1962-63 and was awarded an M.A. in 1965 and a B.Litt. in 1967. Her D.Litt. was awarded by Oxford in 1993. == Career == Professor Treggiari started teaching at various institutions in London from 1964, including Goldsmiths’ College (part-time) and the North-Western Polytechnic. She then taught at the University of Ottawa 1970-82 and at Stanford 1982-2001, where she was Anne T. & Robert M. Bass Professor in the School of Humanities and Sciences from 1992.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lmh.ox.ac.uk/getdoc/8b614f07-65f5-4c2c-aad1-aef15509be1e/Prof-Susan-Treggiari.aspx|title=LMH, Oxford - Professor Susan Treggiari|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113010101/http://www.lmh.ox.ac.uk/getdoc/8b614f07%2D65f5%2D4c2c%2Daad1%2Daef15509be1e/Prof%2DSusan%2DTreggiari.aspx|archive-date=13 January 2017|dead-url=yes|access-date=22 March 2017|df=dmy-all}} Page archived Fri, 13 Jan 2017 13:24:40 GMT In 1993 she was awarded the Charles J. Goodwin Award of Merit of the [[Society for Classical Studies|American Philological Association]].{{Cite web|url=https://classicalstudies.org/awards-and-fellowships/list-previous-goodwin-award-winners|title=List of previous Goodwin awards winners - Society for Classical Scholars|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=22 March 2017}} She has been a member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] since 1995, and has also held the following fellowships: * [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim Fellow]] (1995–96), * Visiting Fellow of [[Brasenose College, Oxford|Brasenose College]] (1976–77) * Visiting fellow of [[All Souls College, Oxford|All Souls College]] (1995–96), and an Honorary Fellow of [[Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford|Lady Margaret Hall]] (2011–). She is a general editor of the [[Oxford University Press|Clarendon Press]] Ancient History Series (1994-), has been Joint Editor of ''[[Classical News and Views]] /[[Echos du monde classique,|Echos du monde classique]]''[[Echos du monde classique,|,]] (1974–81) President of the [[Association of Ancient Historians]] and of the [[Society for Classical Studies|American Philological Association]]. She is a founding member of the Institute for Digital Archaeology Women in Classics Series and with Dr. [[Miriam T. Griffin|Miriam Griffin]] co-hosted the inaugural Women in Classics Dinner at Somerville College, Oxford.{{Cite web|url=http://digitalarchaeology.org.uk/advisory-board/|title=Advisory Board - Institute for Digital Archaeology|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=22 March 2017}} She is also a consultant on the [[Oxford English Dictionary]].{{Cite web|url=http://public.oed.com/the-oed-today/rewriting-the-oed/consultants-advisers-and-contributors/|title=Consultants, advisors and contributors - Oxford English Dictionary|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=22 March 2017}} == Critical reception == Her work ''Roman Marriage. Iusti Coniuges from the Time of Cicero to the time of Ulpian'', was reviewed in [[Bryn Mawr Classical Review]], which said: "Susan Treggiari, with her superb command of the literary and legal sources, now offers us a grand vision of attitudes towards marriage in law and practice among the upper classes. Her inspiration is Crook's ''Law and Life of Rome 90 B.C.-A.D. 212'', and her intention is to describe the institution of marriage at Rome. The result is a massive book that (as the title suggests) draws together an enormous amount of information from legal sources as well as from literary and epigraphic quarters. The excellent index and clear sign-posting within chapters will make this a book that all teaching Roman social history will want."{{Cite web|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/1992/03.03.19.html|title=Bryn Mawr Classical Review 03.03.19|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=22 March 2017}} A similarly favorable review was published in [[Classical Philology (journal)|Classical Philology]], which said: "it is indispensable to all scholars who have any interest whatsoever in Roman marriage. In many respects, T.'s study is a counterpart to P. E. Corbett's The Roman Law of Marriage (Oxford, 1930), one of the few standard Roman law treatises that is also in English. But while T. does not avoid discussing legal sources, her concern is more with the social institution of marriage, and with what might be called its cultural dynamics as they emerge especially from literary and legal sources."{{cite journal|jstor=270019|title=Review on JSTOR|last=|first=|date=|website=}} A review in Bryn Mawr Classical Review of ''Terentia, Tullia and Publilia. The women of Cicero’s family'' concluded: "This will be an extremely useful book for teachers and students taking courses about Roman women. Little previous knowledge is expected from readers, and short introductory sections provide basic information about Roman politics, law and society. It is difficult to say anything new about evidence which is generally well-known and thoroughly discussed, but having it all summarised in one place for the first time is in itself very helpful, and serves its avowed purpose of leaving readers to make up their own minds. Everything is presented in a clear and lucid style with a careful avoidance of going beyond what the sources can support."{{Cite web|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2008/2008-07-06.html|title=Bryn Mawr Classical Review 2008.07.06|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=22 March 2017}} ==Works== ===Books=== * ''Roman freedmen during the late Republic'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1969, re-issued, [[Oxford University Press]], 2000) * ''Cicero's Cilician Letters, translated with an introduction and notes'' (London Association of Classical Teachers Original Records no. 10, 1973, second edition 1997) * ''Roman Marriage. Iusti coniuges from the time of Cicero to the time of Ulpian'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1991, paperback edition 1993) * ''Roman social history'' (London: Routledge, Classical Foundations, 2002) * ''Terentia, Tullia and Publilia. The women of Cicero’s family'' (London: Routledge, Women of Antiquity, 2007) ===Articles=== ====Articles on Roman history in journals and books==== * ‘Pompeius' freedman biographer again’, ''Classical Review'' 19 (1969) 264–266 * ‘The freedmen of Cicero’, ''Greece and Rome'' 16 (1969) 195–204 * ‘Cicero, Horace and mutual friends: Lamiae and Varrones Murenae’, ''Phoenix'' 27 (1973) 245–261 * ‘Domestic staff at Rome in the Julio-Claudian period’, ''Social History/Histoire sociale'' 6 (1973) 241–255 * ‘Roman social history: recent interpretations’, ''Social History/Histoire sociale'' 8 (1975) 149–164 * ‘Jobs in the household of Livia’, ''Papers of the British School at Rome'' 43 (1975) 48–77 * ‘Family life among the staff of the Volusii’, ''Transactions of the American Philological Association'' 105 (1975) 393–401 * ‘Jobs for women’, ''American Journal of Ancient History'' 1 (1976) 76–104 * ‘Lower-class women in the Roman economy’, ''Florilegium'' 1 (1979) 65–86 * ‘Sentiment and property: some Roman attitudes’, A. Parel and T. Flanagan eds., ''Theories of property. Aristotle to the present'' (Waterloo: [[Wilfrid Laurier Press]], 1979) 53–85 * ‘Urban labour in Rome: mercennarii and tabernarii’, Peter Garnsey ed., ''Non-slave labour in the Greco-Roman world'' (Cambridge: Cambridge Philological Society, 1980) 48–64 * ‘Mihi aqua haeret (Cic. QF 2.6.2)’, ''Liverpool Classical Monthly'' 5 (1980) 187–188 * ‘Contubernales in CIL vi’, ''Phoenix'' 35 (1981) 42–69 * ‘Concubinae’, ''Papers of the British School at Rome'' 49 (1981) 59–81 * ‘Consent to Roman marriage: who, why and how?’, ''Classical Views/Echos du monde classique'' 26 (n.s. 1) (1982) 34–44 * ‘Women as property in the early Roman Empire’, in D.K. Weisberg, ed., ''Women and the law. A social and historical perspective'' (Cambridge, Mass.: Schenkman, 1982) ii pp. 7–33 * ‘Digna condicio: betrothals in the Roman upper class’, ''Classical Views'' 28 (n.s. 3) (1984) 419–451 * ‘Iam proterva fronte: matrimonial advances by Roman women’, J.W. Eadie and J. Ober eds., ''The Craft of the ancient historian: Essays in honour of Chester G. {{For|the article about the 1961 film adaptation|The Children's Hour (film)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use American English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox play | name = The Children's Hour | image = The-Children's-Hour-1934-FE.jpg | caption = First edition 1934 | writer = [[Lillian Hellman]] | characters ={{plainlist| * Evelyn Munn * Mrs Lily Mortar * Peggy Rogers * Helen Burton * Lois Fisher * Catherine * Rosalie Wells * Mary Tilford * Karen Wright * Martha Dobie * Doctor Joseph Cardin * Agatha * Mrs Amelia Tilford * A Grocery Boy }} | premiere = {{Start date|1934|11|20}} | place = [[Maxine Elliott Theatre]], New York City | orig_lang = English | genre = Drama | subject = A child's lies destroy the lives of two women at a boarding school for girls }}
'''''The Children's Hour''''' is a 1934 American play by [[Lillian Hellman]]. It is a drama set in an all-girls [[boarding school]] run by two women, Karen Wright and Martha Dobie. An angry student, Mary Tilford, runs away from the school and to avoid being sent back she tells her grandmother that the two headmistresses are having a [[lesbian]] affair. The accusation proceeds to destroy the women's careers, relationships and lives.
The play was first staged on Broadway at the [[Maxine Elliott Theatre]] in 1934, produced and directed by [[Herman Shumlin]]. In 1936 it was presented in Paris and at London's [[Gate Theatre Studio]].
== Synopsis ==
Two women, Karen Wright and Martha Dobie, have worked hard to build a girls' boarding school in a refurbished farmhouse. They run and teach the school with the somewhat unwelcome help of Lily Mortar, Martha's aunt. One pupil, Mary Tilford, is mischievous, disobedient, and untruthful, and often leads the other girls into trouble. One day, when Mary feigns illness and is being examined by Dr. Joe Cardin, a physician who is Mary's cousin and also Karen's fiancé, Martha asks Lily whether she would like to go back to traveling to the places she misses, now that they can afford it. Lily becomes angry and starts shouting about how, whenever Joe is around, Martha becomes irritable, unreasonable and jealous, taking her jealousy of Joe out on her. Two of Mary's friends, listening at the door trying to discover Mary's condition, overhear Lily's outburst.
Mary is found healthy and is sent to her room and squeezes the information out of the girls. Mary plans to ask her grandmother, Amelia Tilford—who not only indulges her but who also helped Karen and Martha a great deal in setting up the school—to allow her not to return. When Amelia refuses, Mary cleverly twists what the girls had overheard. With the help of several well-crafted lies and a book that the girls have been reading in secret, Mary convinces her grandmother that Karen and Martha are having a lesbian affair. On hearing this, Amelia Tilford begins contacting the parents of Mary's classmates. Shortly, most of Mary's friends have been pulled out of school. Rosalie Wells, a student whose mother is abroad, stays with Mary.
On discovering that Rosalie is vulnerable, Mary blackmails her into corroborating everything she says. When Karen and Martha realize why all their pupils were pulled out of their school in a single night, they go to Mrs. Tilford's residence to confront her. Amelia tells Mary to repeat her story. When Karen points out an inconsistency, Mary pretends to have been covering for Rosalie, who reluctantly corroborates Mary's story for fear of being exposed herself. Resolving to take Amelia to court, Martha and Karen leave.
Seven months later, after Martha and Karen have lost the case, everyone still believes that they were lovers. When Lily returns from abroad to take care of her niece, the women are angry with her for not having stayed in the country in order to testify to their innocence. Meanwhile, Joe, who has remained loyal throughout, has found a job in a distant location. He tries to convince Karen and Martha to come with him and start over. As Martha goes to prepare dinner, Joe continues his attempts to persuade Karen, who now believes that she has ruined his life and destroyed everything that she and Martha had worked so hard to achieve.
At Karen's insistence, Joe reluctantly asks her whether she and Martha had ever been lovers. When Karen says that they were not, he readily believes her. Nevertheless, Karen decides that she and Joe must part. She explains that things can never be the same between them after all that they have been through. She asks Joe to leave and he refuses. He agrees to leave if Karen will think things through before finalizing the break-up. When Martha returns and finds out from Karen what has happened, she is consumed with guilt. Her discovery that she might indeed have feelings for Karen overwhelms and terrifies her. Before Martha tells Karen how she feels, Karen tells Martha that she would like to relocate in the morning and wants her to come with her. Martha says it's impossible for them to live comfortably again and eventually admits her feelings for Karen. Karen responds dismissively, saying that they never felt this way for each other. Martha continues, but Karen tells Martha that she is tired and they can talk about it in the morning. As Karen sits in her room, she hears a shot. Martha has killed herself. Shortly after, Amelia Tilford arrives to beg Karen's forgiveness, since Mary's lies have now been uncovered. Karen explains to her that it is too late: Mary's lies, together with the community's willingness to believe and spread malicious gossip, have destroyed three innocent lives.
==History== [[File:Lillian-Hellman-1935.jpg|thumb|upright|Lillian Hellman in 1935]] After her graduation from New York University, Lillian Hellman was a play reader in the office of theatrical producer [[Herman Shumlin]]. In May 1934 Hellman asked Shumlin to read a play of her own—the sixth draft of ''The Children's Hour''. He read it as she waited. After he read the first act Shumlin said, "Swell". After reading the second act he said, "I hope it keeps up". After reading the third act he said, "I'll produce it."<ref name="NYT Obit Shumlin">{{cite news |last=Pace |first=Eric |date=June 15, 1979 |title=Herman Shumlin, 80, Dies, Leading Producer‐Director |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/06/15/archives/herman-shumlin-80-dies-leading-producerdirector-other-hits-to-his.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=2016-10-07 }}</ref>
Shumlin and Hellman worked through the details of the production together over the next months. Shumlin felt the title of the play was misleading and wanted Hellman to change it; but Hellman loved it and refused. Hellman recalled being rudely treated by [[Lee Shubert]], then-owner of the Maxine Elliott Theatre, at a rehearsal. Shumlin faced Shubert down and barked, "That girl, as you call her, is the author of the play."<ref name="NYT Obit Shumlin"/>
After writing one unsuccessful play with [[Louis Kronenberger]], Hellman wrote ''The Children's Hour'' as an exercise, to teach herself how to write a play. Believing that she would do better to find a subject based in fact,<ref name="Paris Review">{{cite magazine |last1=Hollander |first1=Anne |author-link1=Anne Hollander |last2=Marquand |first2=John |date=Winter–Spring 1965 |title=Lillian Hellman, The Art of Theater No. 1 |url=http://www.theparisreview.org/interviews/4463/the-art-of-theater-no-1-lillian-hellman |magazine=[[The Paris Review]] |issue=33 |access-date=2016-10-23 }}</ref> [[Dashiell Hammett]] suggested the idea for the play to Hellman after he read a book titled ''Bad Companions'' (1930),<ref>{{cite book |last=Roughead |first=William |year=1931 |orig-year=1930 |chapter=Closed doors; or, The great Drumsheugh case |title=Bad Companions |location=New York |publisher=Duffield & Green |oclc=377218}}</ref> a [[True crime|true-crime]] anthology by [[William Roughead]].<ref name="TCM These Three">{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/thismonth/article/?cid=18608&rss=mrqe |title=These Three |last=Miller |first=Frank |date= |website= |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies]] |access-date=2016-10-22 }}</ref> It related an incident that took place in 1810 at a school in Edinburgh, Scotland. A student named Jane Cumming accused her schoolmistresses, Jane Pirie and Marianne Woods, of having an affair in the presence of their pupils. Dame Cumming Gordon, the accuser's influential grandmother, advised her friends to remove their daughters from the boarding school. Within days the school was deserted and the two women had lost their livelihood. Pirie and Woods sued and eventually won, both in court and on appeal, but given the damage done to their lives, their victory was considered hollow.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=February 25, 2009 |title=Drumsheugh: Lesbian sex row rocked society |url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/drumsheugh-lesbian-sex-row-rocked-society-1-1193371 |newspaper=[[The Scotsman]] |access-date=2016-10-22 }}</ref>
== Production == Produced and directed by Herman Shumlin, ''The Children's Hour'' opened November 20, 1934, at the [[Maxine Elliott Theatre]] in New York City. The settings by [[Aline Bernstein]] were executed by Sointu Syrjala. The three-act drama closed in July 1936 after 691 performances.<ref name="IBDb Premiere">{{cite web |url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/the-childrens-hour-9381 |title=The Children's Hour |publisher=[[Internet Broadway Database]] |access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref>
===Cast=== [[File:The-Children's-Hour-1935-1.jpg|thumb|260px|[[Robert Keith (actor)|Robert Keith]], [[Anne Revere]], Florence McGee, Katherine Emery and Katherine Emmet in the original Broadway production of ''The Children's Hour'' (1934)]] * [[Eugenia Rawls]] as Peggy Rogers<ref name="NYT Review">{{cite news |last=Atkinson |first=Brooks |authorlink=Brooks Atkinson |date=November 21, 1934 |title=The Play: 'The Children's Hour', Being a Tragedy of Life in a Girls' Boarding House|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1934/11/21/archives/the-play-the-childrens-hour-being-a-tragedy-of-life-in-a-girls.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=2016-10-22 }}</ref> * Aline McDermott as Mrs. Lily Mortar<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Elizabeth Seckel as Evelyn Munn<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Lynne Fisher as Helen Burton<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Jacqueline Rusling as Lois Fisher<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Barbara Leeds as Catherine<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Barbara Beals as Rosalie Wells<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Florence McGee as Mary Tilford<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Katherine Emery as Karen Wright<ref name="NYT Review"/> * [[Anne Revere]] as Martha Dobie<ref name="NYT Review"/> * [[Robert Keith (actor)|Robert Keith]] as Dr. Joseph Cardin<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Edmonia Nolley as Agatha<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Katherine Emmet as Mrs. Amelia Tilford<ref name="NYT Review"/> * Jack Tyler as A Grocery Boy<ref name="NYT Review"/>
The financial and critical success of the New York production encouraged Shumlin to present ''The Children's Hour'' in other cities. In December 1935, authorities in Boston declared that the play did not meet the standards of the [[Watch and Ward Society]] and that it could not be performed there the following month as scheduled. Shumlin filed a $250,000 suit for damages, but in February 1936 a Federal judge refused to prevent the city from interfering in the presentation of the play.<ref name="Banned Plays">{{cite book |last=Sova |first=Dawn B. |date=2004 |title=Banned Plays: Censorship Histories of 125 Stage Dramas |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ikvxgoS_VTAC&pg=PA48 |location=New York |publisher=[[Infobase Publishing|Facts On File]] |pages=49–51 |isbn=9781438129938}}</ref>{{Rp|49–50}}<ref>{{cite news |last=Associated Press |first= |date=December 15, 1935|title='Children's Hour' Banned in Boston |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/12/15/archives/childrens-hour-banned-in-boston-mayor-acts-after-report-by-city.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=2016-10-23 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Associated Press |first= |date=December 27, 1935|title=Boston Sued on Play Ban |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/12/27/archives/boston-sued-on-play-ban-250000-damages-are-sought-over-the.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=2016-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Associated Press |first= |date=February 25, 1936|title=Boston Play Ban Holds |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1936/02/25/archives/boston-play-ban-holds-federal-judge-refuses-to-forbid-action.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=2016-10-23 }}</ref> In January 1936, a municipal censorship ordinance was used to decline granting a performance permit for ''The Children's Hour'' in Chicago.<ref name="Banned Plays"/>{{Rp|50}}<ref>{{cite news |last=Associated Press |first= |date=January 10, 1936|title='The Children's Hour' is Weighed in Chicago|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1936/01/10/archives/-the-childrens-hour-is-weighed-in-chicago-theatre-guild-head-says.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=2016-10-23 }}</ref>
''Les Innocentes'', André Bernheim's French-language translation of ''The Children's Hour'', was first presented April 21, 1936, at the [[Théâtre Hébertot|Théâtre des Arts]] in Paris.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hellman |first1=Lillian |last2=Bernheim |first2=André |date=1936 |title=Les Innocentes: pièce en trois actes et quatre tableaux, adaptée de l'anglais par André Bernheim |location=Paris |publisher=L'Illustration |oclc=458488838 |quote=Paris, théâtre des Arts, 21 avril 1936.}}</ref> Although the [[Lord Chamberlain]] [[Theatres Act 1843|banned]] the public performance of ''The Children's Hour'' in Great Britain in March 1935,<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=March 12, 1935|title=American Play Banned|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E05EFD8113FE53ABC4A52DFB566838E629EDE&legacy=true |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=2016-10-23 }}</ref> the play was presented in its entirety on November 12, 1936, at a private performance at the [[Gate Theatre Studio]] in London, managed by [[Norman Marshall (theatre director)|Norman Marshall]].<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=November 13, 1936|title='The Children's Hour' is Hailed in London|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1936/11/13/archives/-the-childrens-hour-is-hailed-in-london-production-at-gate-theatre-.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=2016-10-23 }}</ref>
==Reception== {{expand section|date=October 2016}} Screenwriter and playwright [[Paddy Chayefsky]] considered ''The Children's Hour'' to be one of the most carefully structured plays ever written, and learned play-structure in his youth by copying in longhand the entire script.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/09/obituaries/paddy-chayefsky-1923-1981.html|title=PADDY CHAYEFSKY, 1923-1981|last=Cantor|first=Arthur|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 9, 1981|accessdate=May 5, 2017}}</ref>
===Accolades=== ''The Children's Hour'' was in serious consideration for the [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] for 1934–35. The award was presented instead to [[Zoë Akins]]' play ''[[The Old Maid (play)|The Old Maid]]''. Accused of rejecting Hellman's play because of its controversial subject—one of the Pulitzer judges had refused to see it—the selection committee replied that ''The Children's Hour'' was not eligible for the award because it was based on a court case and was therefore not an original drama. Critics responded that since ''The Old Maid'' was based on a novella by Edith Wharton, it also should have been deemed ineligible. Angered by the Pulitzer Prize decision, the [[New York Drama Critics' Circle]] began awarding its own annual [[New York Drama Critics' Circle#New York Drama Critics' Circle Award|prize for drama]] the following year.<ref name="Banned Plays"/>{{Rp|50}}
==Revivals== [[File:Playbill Cover for The Children's Hour at Coronet Theatre.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Patricia Neal]], Iris Mann and [[Kim Hunter]] in the 1952 Coronet Theatre production directed by Lillian Hellman]] Lillian Hellman directed a Broadway revival of ''The Children's Hour'', produced by [[Kermit Bloomgarden]] and presented December 18, 1952 – May 30, 1953, at the [[Eugene O'Neill Theatre|Coronet Theatre]]. The cast included [[Kim Hunter]] as Karen Wright, [[Patricia Neal]] as Martha Dobie, Iris Mann as Mary Tilford, and Katherine Emmet reprising her original role as Mrs. Amelia Tilford.<ref name="IBDb Revival">{{cite web |url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/the-childrens-hour-2205 |title=The Children's Hour |publisher=Internet Broadway Database |access-date=2016-10-23}}</ref> The revised stage production was construed as an implied criticism of the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]].<ref name="eNotes">{{cite web |url=http://www.enotes.com/childrens-hour/ |title=The Children's Hour Summary / Study Guide |publisher=eNotes |accessdate=2009-02-19}}</ref>
In 2008 [[Sarah Frankcom]] directed a production at the [[Royal Exchange, Manchester|Royal Exchange]] in [[Manchester]]. It starred [[Maxine Peake]] (who won a [[Manchester Evening News Theatre Awards|MEN Award]]) as Karen Wright, Charlotte Emmerson as Martha Dobie, [[Kate O'Flynn]] (who won a [[TMA Awards|TMA Award]]) as Mary Tilford and Milo Twomey as Dr Joseph Cardin.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
A revival starring [[Keira Knightley]] and [[Elisabeth Moss]], directed by [[Ian Rickson]], was presented at London's [[Harold Pinter Theatre]] January 22 – May 7, 2011.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12414889 |title=Keira Knightley 'wins spurs' with West End stage return |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=10 February 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisistheatre.com/londonshows/childrenshour.html |title=The Children's Hour |website=thisistheatre.com |publisher= |access-date=2016-10-23}}</ref>
==Adaptations==
In 1936, the play was made into a film directed by [[William Wyler]]. However, because of the [[Production Code]], the story was adapted into a heterosexual love triangle, the controversial name of the play was changed, and the movie was eventually released as ''[[These Three]]''.<ref name="eNotes" /> Hellman reportedly worked on the screenplay, keeping virtually all of the play's original dialogue, and was satisfied with the result, saying the play's central theme of gossip was unaffected by the changes.
In 1961, the play was adapted, with its lesbian theme intact, for the film ''[[The Children's Hour (1961 film)|The Children's Hour]]'', also directed by Wyler and starring [[Audrey Hepburn]], [[Shirley MacLaine]], and [[James Garner]]. In the UK, New Zealand and Australia it was released under the title ''The Loudest Whisper''.
In 1971 the play was produced for the radio by the BBC in its Saturday Night Theatre series starring Jill Bennett and Prunella Scales.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/3a069f80ff5845bea95d23c132ce92e9|title=Saturday-Night Theatre: The Children's Hour|date=April 22, 1971|publisher=|issue=2476|pages=19|accessdate=January 20, 2018|via=BBC Genome}}</ref>
In 1994 the play was again produced for the radio by the BBC in its Monday Play series, starring Clare Holman, Buffy Davis, Miriam Margolyes and Margaret Robertson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/4f77f71410ba4749a7822e9390b77bf1|title=The Monday Play: The Children's Hour|date=August 25, 1994|publisher=|issue=3685|pages=97|accessdate=January 20, 2018|via=BBC Genome}}</ref>

[[administrative regions of Greece|administrative region]] of [[Central Macedonia]] and the [[Decentralized Administration of Macedonia and Thrace]].{{cite
